AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Cotulla, Texas: location where Carlos Martinez-Romero's investigatory stop took place, approximately sixty-eight miles from the Texas-Mexico border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate 35: road where Carlos Martinez-Romero was traveling when stopped by Border Patrol Agent David Fitzgerald, with a speed limit of seventy miles per hour
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas-Mexico border: border near where the stop of Carlos Martinez-Romero occurred
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas: state with constitution protecting individuals from unreasonable searches and seizures and location of court proceedings
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexico: country of Carlos Martinez-Romero's citizenship, from which he crossed with a valid border-crosser card
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country with constitution protecting individuals from unreasonable searches and seizures
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Court of Criminal Appeals: court that has made rulings on roving border patrol stops, establishing standards for reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.area near the Texas-Mexico border: region relevant to the case of Carlos Martinez-Romero, with guidelines limiting reasonable proximity to stops conducted within fifty miles of the border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Edna, Texas: vehicle registration location and origin of alien-smuggling vehicles, suburb of Dallas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dallas: larger city and registration location for some alien-smuggling vehicles
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Austin: larger city that smugglers may travel to
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.San Antonio: larger city that smugglers may travel to
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S.-Mexico border: border region relevant to smuggling activities and vehicle stops, also the location of a vehicle stop in Carlos Martinez-Romero's case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dallas and Austin and San Antonio: cities that smugglers often travel to
